Oracle has confirmed a continued rise in data center deals, with the value of its lease commitments totalling $248 billion as of November 30, 2025.

The company¬†planned to raise Capex¬†to $50 billion this fiscal year, up from an earlier forecast of $35 billion.

But now, we know Oracle has nearly $250 billion in data center and cloud capacity leasing deals set to last 15-19 years, marking a considerable 148% increase since the previous quarter in August 2025.

"As of November 30, 2025, we had $248 billion of additional lease commitments, substantially all related to data centers and cloud capacity arrangements, that are generally expected to commence between the third quarter of fiscal 2026 and fiscal 2028 and for terms of fifteen to nineteen years that were not reflected on our condense consolidated balance sheets as of November 30, 2025," the company wrote in its SEC¬†filing.

Are soft skills worth as much as technical expertise?

The answer is a clear yes from Stefan Riedmann, Associate Director at BCS Consultancy. In the latest episode of the Talent Talks podcast, Stefan, alongside SARAH DAVENPORT, Capstone's Managing Director, and OLI C., Data Center and Real Estate Sector Lead, explore the changing hiring trends in the data center industry. Rigid hiring practices, demanding sector-specific experience for every role, have shifted due to rapid growth and the talent crunch.

On hiring, Stefan gives his view, prioritizing the human element:

"I look more into the soft skill side. I look more into what the right attitudes are that this person has, and do they bring the right mindset to deliver projects in this exciting but challenging environment?"

He firmly believes that technical knowledge can be learned quickly, using BCS as an example, with the embedded expertise available for new joiners to "soak up like a sponge". Project Management, ultimately, is a people business in managing stakeholders and expectations.

If you're considering a move into the mission-critical world from another sector (like healthcare, logistics, or construction), this episode is a must-listen. Your ability to adapt is your most valuable asset.

Listen to the full episode through the link in the comments for Stefan's perspective on talent acquisition in the data center sector.

#DataCenters #SoftSkills #CareerTransition

Rolls-Royce Sets a New Standard for Sustainability in Emergency Power üìå 

The data center industry is under immense pressure to reduce its carbon footprint while maintaining 24/7 reliability. Rolls-Royce has just raised the bar with a groundbreaking move: introducing Environmental Product Declarations (EPDs) for its mtu-brand emergency power generators.
What does this mean?

EPDs provide full lifecycle transparency from raw material extraction to end-of-life recycling covering resource consumption, emissions, waste generation, and recyclability. Developed in partnership with Sphera and registered in the international Environdec system, these declarations make sustainability measurable and verifiable.
Why it matters:

Reduced Maintenance Costs & Emissions: Extended service intervals mean quarterly checks instead of monthly, cutting costs and environmental impact.

Sustainable Fuel Compatibility: mtu generators now run on hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) and e-fuels, slashing CO‚ÇÇ, NOx, and particulate emissions by over 90%.

Industry Collaboration: A new framework agreement with AVK-SEG secures production capacity for mtu Series 4000 generators and supports low-carbon solutions for UK data centers.

As Tobias Ostermaier, President of Stationary Power Solutions at Rolls-Royce Power Systems AG- puts it:

"This is our response to growing demand from customers. Sustainability is now transparent, measurable, and actionable."

The takeaway: Rolls-Royce isn‚Äôt just supplying power it‚Äôs powering the future of sustainable data centers.

#DataCenters #Sustainability #GreenEnergy #CarbonReduction 
#EnergyEfficiency #PowerSolutions #CleanTech #FutureOfEnergy #InnovationInAction #RenewableEnergy #RollsRoyce #mtuPower #AVK

post_content:
Over the past year, PJM Interconnection has become the focal point of a national challenge: meeting skyrocketing electricity demand while keeping power affordable and reliable.
¬†
From D.C. to Chicago, North America's largest wholesale market is wrestling with sharply rising prices, a capacity market under stress and unprecedented load growth driven in part by AI data centers and other large energy users. As more governors and policymakers raise concerns, it‚Äôs clear how PJM responds will influence markets and policy well beyond its borders.
¬†
In a piece shared with Latitude Media, I explore the fundamental risks in #PJM‚Äôs current policy discussions, the possibility that well-intended reforms could unintentionally weaken one of the most valuable, proven tools we have: #demandresponse delivered through #virtualpowerplants (VPPs).
¬†
Demand response has shown that it can prevent emergencies, avoid costly peak generation and maximize the capacity of the existing grid. PJM currently relies on roughly 8 GW of it. And as new loads come online faster than new supply, this resource will only become more essential. Yet some proposals on the table could reduce participation or create inequitable structures that disincentivize the very flexibility PJM needs most. If that happens, we lose reliability, affordability and a critical resource PJM depends on.
¬†
There are four principles that are critical to getting this right:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Establish a fair curtailment hierarchy: Large new loads that haven‚Äôt committed enough flexible capacity should be curtailed before customers who have made firm commitments to provide grid relief. Reliability depends on respecting the value contributors bring to the system.
¬†
2Ô∏è‚É£ Dispatch flexibility when it‚Äôs actually needed: A ‚Äúgo last‚Äù model for certain large loads isn‚Äôt just unfair, it‚Äôs operationally risky. All participants must be called upon when system stress occurs, not after reserves are depleted.
¬†
3Ô∏è‚É£ Enable private VPPs and flexible capacity solutions: If a large load can‚Äôt easily curtail, it should be allowed to purchase accredited flexibility from other market participants. This creates new value streams, accelerates VPP development, and ensures the system gets the relief it needs.
¬†
4Ô∏è‚É£ Keep new demand response products open and inclusive: As PJM designs solutions, they must preserve broad participation. Diversity of load types is a core strength of DR and #VPPs, not a complication.
¬†
It's not about choosing between #datacenters and existing customers, or between innovation and reliability. It's about aligning incentives so that all energy users can actively contribute to a resilient grid. I‚Äôm optimistic that thoughtful policy design can unlock even more capacity, more innovation and more fairness across the system.

AI power demand is rising at a pace no one expected.

Some reports say energy requirements for AI data centers could grow more than thirtyfold by 2035.

That sounds alarming.

It is not the full story.

A closer look shows something different happening inside the industry.

Operators are not waiting for the grid to catch up.

They are redesigning how data centers interact with power in the first place.

Energy storage systems are shifting workloads to off-peak hours.

Virtual power plants are helping stabilize entire regions.

Flexible compute strategies are reducing strain when the grid needs relief.

Advanced cooling is supporting higher density without higher risk.

Research from Duke University shows the impact clearly.

If data centers operate flexibly for even a small portion of the year, the U.S. grid can support tens of gigawatts of new load without building additional power plants.

The real challenge is not generation.

It is transmission.

Delivering power to the locations where AI growth is happening is now the biggest bottleneck.

Timelines for new substations and transmission lines stretch five to ten years in many markets.

This is where innovation matters most.

Smarter infrastructure.

Faster permitting.

Better coordination with utilities.

More adaptive designs inside data centers.

As Jenny Gerson, Senior Director of Sustainability, explains, ‚ÄúThis is not a crisis spinning out of control but a two-sided infrastructure challenge where transmission upgrades and smarter data center design must work together.‚Äù

AI is not pushing the grid to the edge.

It is accelerating a modernization cycle that was overdue.

Read the full analysis from Jenny and explore why AI driven growth is pushing the industry toward smarter, more resilient power strategies.

https://lnkd.in/gcuD8UU7

For enterprises, it means generating power where it‚Äôs used, storing it intelligently, and reducing exposure to utility risk.
Even supplying 30% of a facility‚Äôs load changes the equation ‚Äî you‚Äôre no longer just consuming power, you‚Äôre actively managing it.

That kind of control brings budget certainty, operational resilience, and a real competitive edge ‚Äî especially for power-hungry operations like data centers.

You just closed a 50MW power deal. Congratulations. 

Now comes the hard part: finding $30-40M in¬†CapEx¬†to build the facility before you can deploy a single ASIC.¬†
Mobile datacenter. Cooling infrastructure. Electrical distribution. Transformer procurement. Civil work. The list¬†of¬†compounds. 

Meanwhile, your competitors are hashing. The difficulty adjusts. And your capital sits frozen in concrete and metal instead of where it¬†actually generates¬†revenue ‚Äî on the¬†hashboards.¬†
The traditional model demands¬†that¬†you become a construction company before you become a mining company.¬†¬†
¬†
You wanted to scale¬†up¬†MW capacity.¬†¬†
¬†
Instead,¬†you're¬†getting¬†your capital frozen.¬†
¬†
Here's the uncomfortable truth: Every dollar locked in infrastructure is a dollar that¬†can't¬†buy the next-generation machines when they drop.¬†¬†
¬†
It's debt capacity you¬†can't¬†leverage.¬†It's¬†an¬†optionality¬†you've¬†surrendered.¬†
We've¬†been told this is "just how mining works."¬†
¬†
But when your IRR¬†(Internal Rate of Return)¬†gets compressed because you built the facility instead of leasing it, when you¬†can't¬†pivot to the next hardware cycle because¬†you're¬†asset-heavy...

Is the¬†CapEx-first model¬†actually working? Or are we all just pretending it is? 

¬†
#BitcoinMining #Infrastructure #CapEx #MiningOperations #AssetManagement

Hot Racks! "Say Hello to My Little Queue!"

This week‚Äôs reality check comes from Andrew Schaper‚Äôs eye-opening report, "Powered Land: A Market for Lemons", which politely explains that the much-hyped ‚Äúdata center land rush‚Äù is mostly people sprinting toward dirt that doesn‚Äôt actually turn on. Less than 0.25% of marketed ‚Äúdata center-ready‚Äù sites have a viable path to power. The rest are acres cosplaying as campuses.

For years, this worked. You could stack acreage, put together a rendering, talk confidently about ‚Äúpower adjacency,‚Äù and nobody asked too many follow-up questions. The grid was opaque, verification was cheap, and hype + optimism was doing a lot of heavy lifting.

According to Schaper, that era is ending.

Utilities are now charging up to $300K just to run interconnection studies. If you‚Äôre lucky enough to clear that hurdle, you might think you're big time. That‚Äôs when the utility says, ‚ÄúSay hello to my little queue!‚Äù And you don‚Äôt just take a number, you may have to pay up to $50K/MW in security postings to keep it.

Schaper describes this trend as the shift "from a pooling equilibrium to a separating equilibrium." The last 48 mos was the pooling equilibrium, aka "the Fugazi Phase", where you could get some land, throw the word ‚ÄúAI‚Äù on it, and hope nobody asked about interconnection studies. But as utilities crank deposits to nosebleed levels, the market snaps into Schaper's "separating equilibrium", a full-blown reckoning where only the players with real power probability (and bank accounts) survive. 

Yesterday everyone blended in; tomorrow everyone gets exposed. It‚Äôs musical chairs, except the music stops and the utility charges you $15 million to keep the seat.

You can already see the fallout. Volume flippers, option hoarders, and ‚Äúwe‚Äôll figure it out later‚Äù speculators were fine when verification was someone else‚Äôs problem. When the deposits become non-refundable and the queue has a cover charge, the bluff collapses fast.

Meanwhile, the 0.25% with verified capacity, real queue position, and the balance sheet to post security without breaking into a sweat suddenly look very scarce... and very expensive - exactly how functioning markets are supposed to work.

Bottom line: the land rush phase is over. The power capitalization phase has begun. If your site can‚Äôt survive first contact with the utility queue, it was never a data center site, it was just dirt with good PR.

If you‚Äôre trying to get powered and not filtered out, you know where to find us. OLH Ventures and PowerPath Partners are already working with the rare 0.25% to turn powered land into actual AI campuses. 

And if you want to see more content like this make sure to like, share and comment and follow Hot Racks! Dishing The Data Center Dirt Since 2025 ‚Ñ¢Ô∏è
 
#DataCenters
#PowerInfrastructure
#GridConstraints
#AIInfrastructure
#UtilityQueues

post_content:
Data Center Teams live by three pillars: Uptime, Power, and Cooling.

These are what keep the lights on. These are what drive revenue. These are what protect reputations.

Operators invest millions into systems and infrastructure to safeguard these pillars‚Äîyet downtime still happens. And when it does, teams are left scratching their heads asking, why?

One reason is surprisingly simple, yet often overlooked: contamination control.

You might wonder, how can dust cause downtime?

Those airborne and settled particulates your team is sweeping around‚Äîor ignoring‚Äîare finding their way inside servers and switches. Over time, they create an insulating layer that traps heat. Left unchecked, this leads to overheating and failure.

Think about your Xbox or PlayStation. Ever notice the cooling fans clogged with dust bunnies? Did your console run hot? Crash more often? Lag? Same concept‚Äîexcept instead of a $500 console, we‚Äôre talking about millions in revenue and your reputation.

Contamination control isn‚Äôt optional. It‚Äôs mission-critical.

If you‚Äôre not addressing it, you‚Äôre leaving uptime to chance.

#Uptime #DataCenter #Power #Cooling #Facilities #Promera

post_content:
Where are the AI Data Center Debt Bodies Buried? A Very Brief Case Study

I have been compiling an AI dossier including datacenters. I am finding that most Private Credit and Private Equity companies have direct, very large,  ownership of Datacenter companies. 

As I've posted previously, much of the datacenter build out will be funded via off balance sheet debt hidden in the global financial circulatory system.  

Private Credit / Private Equity companies will find it easiest to inject the datacenter debt into their insurance affiliates. 

Buried in a 400 page statutory filing reveals that Brookfield owned insurance company ANICO owns nearly $200M in datacenter Cyxtera mortgage debt; cleverly named Project Cyborg. Brookfield bought Cyxtera out of bankruptcy in 2024 and merged it with their main data center company Evoque. (see image). 

While this may be a great investment for ANICO, there is a fairly good chance that Brookfield leveraged their ownership of ANICO to get the larger $750M Cyxtera deal done. 

Let me put it as plainly as possible. There are minimal guardrails in the PE owned insurance industry to prevent the insurance companies from being the bag men of the data center debt bacchanal. 

Even the best intentioned owners of insurance companies, caught up in the competitive deal frenzy may make severe mistakes which their insurance company clients will suffer the consequences of.

Just this week we've seen plunging equity prices of Broadcom, Oracle and former Energy Secretary Rick Perry's Fermi datacenter company. Fermi plunged to a $5B valuation from an IPO value of nearly $15B. Fermi, despite having ZERO revenues, was able to IPO at a $15B value. That's not a typo. A company with ZERO revenue was able to IPO at a $15B valuation. 

Fermi's plunge this week was due to their first anchor tenant cancelling their lease.

#privatecredit
#datacenters
#ai
#privateequity

post_content:
SHANTI BILL ((Sustainable Harnessing and Advancement of Nuclear Energy for Transforming India). 

The SHANTI Bill is an important step in the right direction for India‚Äôs data center, digital, and critical infrastructure ecosystem.

why 
For years, we‚Äôve spoken about sustainability and renewables, but those of us responsible for data centers and mission-critical infrastructure know one hard truth:

24/7 base load power cannot be built on intermittency alone.
By opening up the nuclear sector and enabling public and private participation, including Small Modular Reactors (SMRs), the SHANTI Bill finally acknowledges reality.

From a data center and critical infrastructure perspective, this is not about nuclear vs renewables.

 It‚Äôs about energy resilience, predictability, and sovereignty. SMRs offer clean, reliable base-load power at a scale and stability that aligns far better with hyperscale, BFSI, telecom, and national digital platforms.
How long did it take
‚Äì Policy intent was visible in Budget 2025
‚Äì Cabinet clearance in Dec 2025
‚Äì Parliamentary process underway
‚Äì Effectiveness will follow passage and detailed rulemaking

As India is serious about AI, sovereign cloud, financial systems, and always-on digital services, nuclear has to be treated as strategic infrastructure, not just an energy source.

Energy is no longer an operational concern.
It‚Äôs a national capability decision.

Powering the AI revolution‚Äîresponsibly. Introducing Low Watt Labs‚Ñ¢ (LWL). ‚ö°üåø

AI is accelerating fast, and the infrastructure behind it is hitting a hard constraint:¬†energy.

Why Low Watt Labs‚Ñ¢ exists:
üìà¬†Global AI data center power¬†rising from¬†~446 TWh (2025)¬†to¬†~946 TWh (2030)
üá∫üá∏¬†U.S. demand¬†rising from¬†~205 TWh (2025)¬†to¬†~380 TWh (2030)

To help decouple AI progress from linear energy growth,¬†NasterQuest Inc.¬†is launching¬†Low Watt Labs‚Ñ¢ (LWL)‚Äîour research initiative focused on¬†high-efficiency AI compute.

What we‚Äôre building at LWL
üîß Low-power intelligent chip designs & accelerators
üß† Algorithm‚Äìhardware co-design for performance-per-watt
üìâ Efficiency-first AI techniques (compression, quantization, sparsity, scheduling)
üîÅ IP-first innovation: building and licensing impactful compute IP

We aren‚Äôt just building better AI. We‚Äôre building¬†sustainable foundations¬†for AI at scale.

The work begins now.¬†Follow along for milestones, benchmarks, and breakthroughs. üöÄ

#NasterQuest #LowWattLabs #LWL #AIInfrastructure #Sustainability #SustainableAI #SustainableTech #AI #PerformancePerWatt #GreenTech #DataCenters #FutureOfCompute

At¬†Data Centres Ireland, ServerDomes CEO¬†David Jackson¬†joined us to reveal why the industry must rethink how we build data centers for the AI era ‚Äî and why the dome architecture is the breakthrough the market needs.

In this clip, David breaks down the engineering reality behind high-density compute:

‚ÄúWe use¬†93% less water,¬†27% less power, and we can support¬†5‚Äì25 megawatts on a single acre. And we can deliver a fully commissioned, AI-ready facility within¬†12 months, compared to 18‚Äì30 months for traditional builds.‚Äù
‚Äî David Jackson¬† 

He also explains why the dome exists at all:

‚ÄúHeat rises ‚Äî so we let it rise. Instead of fighting physics, we work with it. That‚Äôs the advantage of a geodesic dome.‚Äù
‚Äî David Jackson¬† 

Why this matters now:
- AI workloads are doubling every few months.
- Power availability is tightening.
- Communities are rejecting hyperscale noise and water consumption.
- Traditional rectangular buildings simply can‚Äôt cool what‚Äôs coming next.

ServerDomes solves this with:
- Hybrid air + immersion cooling
- Natural-convection heat evacuation
- Lower water and power requirements
- Community-friendly design
- Behind-the-meter power options
- Modular scalability to¬†50MW+ campuses

In partnership with¬†Global Green Generation, we‚Äôre bringing this model to Europe, North America, and beyond.

The future of AI infrastructure is efficient, sustainable, and fast to deploy.
ServerDomes is how we get there.

#ServerDomes #AI #DataCenters #Sustainability #GeodesicDome #ImmersionCooling #HighDensityCompute #InfrastructureInnovation #DataCentresIreland #ComputeAtScale

post_content:
Elon Musk may have just revealed the real endgame of the AI race.

Not models.
Not algorithms.
Not even chips.

Space Based Solar Power.

Every major AI company is running into the same wall.

Oracle burned $12B in one quarter building data centers‚Äîand still posted negative free cash flow. Microsoft, Google, and Amazon face the same constraint:

You cannot scale AI faster than you can scale electricity.

The physics is brutal:
‚Ä¢ The US generates ~490 GW of total power
‚Ä¢ AI alone could need 120+ GW by 2035
‚Ä¢ Data centers demand massive cooling, water, land, and years of approvals

This is no longer a software problem. It is an infrastructure problem.

Now zoom out.

SpaceX isn‚Äôt just a rocket company.
It controls:
‚Ä¢ Fully reusable launch systems
‚Ä¢ Mass satellite manufacturing
‚Ä¢ Global orbital infrastructure (Starlink)
‚Ä¢ A vertically integrated AI company (xAI)

The strategic leap is obvious once you see it: If power limits AI on Earth, move compute off Earth.

In orbit:
‚Ä¢ Solar energy runs 24/7
‚Ä¢ No clouds, no night cycles
‚Ä¢ No grid bottlenecks
‚Ä¢ No water cooling constraints

Starship enables scale.
Starlink enables continuous deployment.

Whoever controls launch cadence controls compute capacity.

And right now, only one company launches at that scale.

Others see it coming‚ÄîBlue Origin, Google, former Big Tech leaders buying rocket companies‚Äîbut execution matters more than vision.

This reframes everything.

SpaceX is not competing with AI labs. It‚Äôs positioning itself as the infrastructure layer beneath them.

If orbital compute works:
‚Ä¢ AI companies won‚Äôt fight over power
‚Ä¢ They‚Äôll rent it
‚Ä¢ And the toll road won‚Äôt be on Earth

The AI race may not be won by the best model.

It may be won by whoever owns the energy and compute layer everyone else depends on.

That possibility alone explains why this moment is being underestimated.

Sometimes disruption doesn‚Äôt beat competitors.

It changes the terrain so completely that the old race stops mattering.

#AI #Infrastructure #Energy #SpaceX #Starlink #Compute #DataCenters #FutureOfAI #Technology #Innovation

post_content:
The Trillion-Dollar Race to Fragment the NVIDIA Monopoly ü§ñ
Nvidia‚Äôs ongoing fight to maintain technological and market dominance in #AI inference üí°

For the past ten years, Nvidia has dominated the market for advanced computer chips used in machine learning and artificial intelligence.
Driven by its proprietary #CUDA #software and rapid #innovation, Nvidia became synonymous with AI #processors, briefly reaching a $5 trillion market value this year. Between February and October 2025, Nvidia¬†reported $147.8 billion in sales from chips, network connections, and related hardware supporting AI growth.

Even though Nvidia‚Äôs newest and most powerful processors, the Grace Blackwell series, are selling out quickly, its dominance is starting to weaken. Instead of facing just one competitor, Nvidia is now challenged on many fronts as the industry shifts toward more specialized hardware.

Nvidia‚Äôs largest customers become competitors

The ‚ÄúBig Four‚Äù North American #hyperscalers ‚Äî Google, Amazon Web Services (AWS) , Microsoft, and Meta ‚Äî account for the largest capital expenditures in this sector. Their collective shift to custom silicon is a strategic move to ensure competitiveness.

Google, part of Alphabet Inc., initiated the move toward custom AI chips with its Tensor Processing Units (TPUs). The latest version,¬†TPU v7 ‚ÄòIronwood,‚Äô¬†is optimized for inference. Ironwood features a large shared #memory, enabling up to 9,216 #chips to connect in a single ‚Äòsuperpod,‚Äô which addresses memory constraints in large Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models.

A big thank you again to Pablo Valerio and EE Times | Electronic Engineering Times for the full article with more background and insights via the link below üí°üôèüëá
https://lnkd.in/eFFMp4dE

post_content:
Thanks to everyone who commented on my new role last week and for all the direct messages I received, I really do appreciate it. My new role covers three main areas which I thought i'd share with you below.

1, Our first DC acquisition is the Bank of America site just outside London. We are busy finalising plans to build this out to offer an additional 20MW of capacity that will come online in 2026. We are really excited to be able to offer 20MW in the South East of the UK at a time when AI and HPC capacity is at a premium. I‚Äôll be project managing the site build out and working alongside our partners to bring it online on time and to budget. 

Worth noting we also have a stand alone 2MW hall with separate power feeds, cooling and redundancy that will be available next year as well. This would be ideal for an operator looking for a footprint in the South East who wants complete autonomy over their facility even down to their own MPAN. 

2, I‚Äôm also involved in capacity sales for this site and others that will be announced shorty. So if you are looking to deploy AI / HPC workloads next year in the UK then please contact me and let's have a chat about what we can offer you at this and other sites.

3, The final part of my role is being involved in site selection. Over the last couple of years i‚Äôve built up an amazing eco system of contacts from around the world who have identified sites for me way before they go anywhere near the open market. I still want to hear from you!¬†We have extremely aggressive growth plans for Gravity Edge and we are keen on legacy sites that have scope to be improved and also new builds that have outline planning consent and confirmed power commitments.

Thats all for now so have a great Christmas and here‚Äôs hoping 2026 will be just as busy as 2025 has been.¬†#ai #hpc #colocation #datacenter #aifactory #neocloud #gpu #aicluster #cloudservices #blackrock #digitalgravitypartners

Stu.

ùêìùê°ùêû $80 ùêÅùê¢ùê•ùê•ùê¢ùê®ùêß ùêÉùêöùê≠ùêö ùêÇùêûùêßùê≠ùêûùê´: ùêñùê°ùê≤ ùêàùêÅùêå'ùê¨ ùêÇùêÑùêé ùêíùêöùê≤ùê¨ ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùêÄùêà ùêÅùêÆùê¢ùê•ùêù-ùêéùêÆùê≠ ùêÉùê®ùêûùê¨ùêß'ùê≠ ùêÄùêùùêù ùêîùê©

Arvind Krishna warned us that there‚Äôs ‚Äòno way‚Äô hyperscalers like Google and Amazon will be able to turn a profit at the rate of their data center spending. And it's true. 

Here's what goes into a 1GW AI training facility in 2025:

‚Üí GPUs & accelerators: $35‚Äì45B (50‚Äì60%)
‚Üí Power delivery (substations, transformers, backup): $10‚Äì15B
‚Üí Liquid cooling systems: $6‚Äì10B
‚Üí Building retrofit/shell + networking: $5‚Äì8B
‚Üí Land, permitting, misc.: $2‚Äì4B

‚Üí Total: $65‚Äì80B per gigawatt. Operating costs add another $3‚Äì4.5B annually. Even with aggressive $10‚Äì12B yearly revenue, you're facing 6‚Äì8 years to breakeven, except the hardware refresh cycle hits at 4 years. 

Scale this industry-wide, and you need $8 trillion in capital, requiring $800B in annual profit just to justify the investment. Meanwhile, 50+ GW of new capacity is already planned by 2030, adding electricity demand equivalent to Sweden's total consumption in just five years.

If you achieve AGI or model dominance, you capture exponential value. If you don't, you're stuck with utility-grade margins on commodity hardware.

Speed and vertical integration (xAI Colossus, Oracle-Stargate, etc.) are bending the cost curve, but the fundamental bet remains, either breakthrough or bust.

Energy, capital, and execution velocity, not just GPUs, will decide who wins the AI infrastructure race.

#AI #DataCenters #Energy
author_headline: Former CEO & Executive Director @Cyient | NASSCOM Executive Council and ER&D Chair | Board Member | Angel Investor | Advisor | Intelligent & Digital Engineering Strategist | Technology Enthusiast

post_content:
#Energy_storage used to be a supporting act.
Now it is becoming the #grid.

Sounds dramatic.
It is not.

When India commits ‚Çπ2,250 crore to its first large-scale lithium refinery, that is not climate signaling. That is supply-chain control. Raw materials move upstream for a reason.

When Texas utilities quietly line up another 500 MW of battery storage, pushing past 1 GW, it is not about ‚Äúgreen power.‚Äù It is about keeping the lights on as coal and gas step back.

When CATL, Sungrow Power Supply Co., Ltd., and Samsung SDI Battery Systems pivot capital toward stationary storage ‚Äî signing billion-dollar LFP contracts ‚Äî it tells you something important: batteries are no longer vehicles‚Äô accessories. They are infrastructure.

Residential storage is following the same logic. California homes are turning batteries into grid assets. Solar plus storage is becoming the default, not the exception.

Costs are collapsing too. India‚Äôs effective storage costs dropping toward ‚Çπ2.8/kWh changes bidding math, project IRRs, and deployment speed ‚Äî fast.

Meanwhile, the technology stack keeps evolving. Sodium-ion, long-duration chemistries, modular 6.9 MWh systems, #hybrid_battery_supercapacitor architectures for #data_centers. This is not incremental change. It is system redesign.

And policy is catching up. Grid resilience rules, cybersecurity mandates, post-blackout storage auctions in #Europe. Reliability now has a price ‚Äî and batteries are how you buy it.

The pattern is simple:
Energy storage is moving from ‚Äúadd-on‚Äù to ‚Äúoperating layer.‚Äù

Who owns it, who controls it, and who monetizes flexibility will define power markets through the next decade.

This is not an energy transition story anymore.
It is an infrastructure story.

Complete Report: https://lnkd.in/gQZmSHa7

#BatteryEnergyStorage #BESS #EnergyInfrastructure #GridResilience #EnergyTransition #RenewableEnergy #LithiumIon #SodiumIon #LongDurationStorage #CleanEnergy #PowerMarkets

Mumbai‚Äôs data-centre boom is keeping the city hooked on coal‚Äîand residents are paying the price. An investigation by Luke Barratt, Atika Rehman and Sushmita - for The Guardian reveals how rising electricity demand from data centres‚Äîincluding Amazon-linked sites‚Äîis delaying coal plant closures and worsening pollution and health impacts in neighbourhoods like Mahul: https://loom.ly/BjYAM1M

This report was produced as part of a collaborative cross-border reporting project #DarkSideOfTheBoom, with partners Katadata Indonesia, Prachatai, Katadata Indonesia, Mekong Eye, Malaysiakini, #BicolDotPH, #READr, Down To Earth, #PhilippineCenterforInvestigativeJournalism, IndiaSpend, Tech Policy Press, #TheIrrawaddy, #TheClimateWatch and #TIAS√ÅNG‚Äîsupported by EJN, SourceMaterial and Pulitzer Center: https://loom.ly/x9XChtQ

Looking back, it‚Äôs been a record-breaking year for our global infrastructure.

In the US, we tripled our network traffic and doubled our server fleet to keep up with demand.

Back in Europe, we deployed our very first HPE Gen11 beasts this year, featuring massive 256-core / 512-thread dual AMD EPYC processors, while simultaneously launching our first active servers in our new Denmark datacenter.

Data center development is exploding to meet AI + cloud demand‚Äîand community sentiment is changing just as fast.

In Q2 2025 alone, according to Data Center Watch, 20 projects (~$98B) were  canceled or delayed due to local concerns like power prices, water use, noise, transparency, tax subsidies, and climate impacts.

That‚Äôs why static ‚Äúfeasibility snapshots‚Äù don‚Äôt hold up anymore.

Learnewable just completed our latest 30-day community sentiment + permitting analysis for every U.S. county and county-equivalent for data center development. Here are some highlights from the past 30 days:

‚Ä¢ Over 40% of counties saw a sentiment shift
‚Ä¢ South: changed the most overall and led the country in positive sentiment momentum
‚Ä¢ West: remained the most stable region
‚Ä¢ New Hampshire: least changed 
‚Ä¢ Connecticut and Oklahoma: among the most volatile, with the strongest negative shifts
‚Ä¢ Massachusetts: showed the strongest positive momentum

What you can do with Learnewable:
‚Ä¢ Monitor county-level sentiment + permitting (near real time)
‚Ä¢ Flag early risk and emerging tailwinds before they become headlines
‚Ä¢ Generate Site Scout reports for any location, with optional key stakeholders + contact info to start outreach early 

Learnewable also maps sentiment + permitting for solar, onshore wind, and BESS‚Äîcritical for integrated power planning around data centers.

#datacenters, #siteselection, #permitting, #communityengagement, #AI #infrastructure

The APAC data centre boom is real! 

From Singapore to India, Indonesia to Australia, data centres are scaling at unprecedented speed. What often gets less attention is the critical role of MV & LV infrastructure behind this growth. 

Reliable power distribution, fast deployment, and serviceability are no longer "nice to have" ‚Äî they are business enablers. 

‚ö° MV for resilience
‚ö° LV for efficiency
‚ö° Service for uptime
